title: What's the most depressing song you've ever heard? - Quora

response.answer_text:
The most depressing song I’ve ever heard? It’s gotta be ‘Father and Son’ by Cat Stevens. This song is a story in itself, it consists of both sides of the story, while the “Son” verses are talking about how he can’t stop thinking about all his problems, whilst the “Father” verses talk about how you need to take things easy and let go of your problems once in a while. This song mainly focuses on Cat’s loss of relations with not only his father but also society. He said that ‘father and son’ seems to say everything he wanted to say, and he can’t go on saying it cause you can only say it once it has to do with feeling frustrated, and it’s to do with family and trying to get through to your family as well as trying to get through to society and school. Here are a few quotes from this song: “It's not time to make a changeJust sit down, take it slowlyYou're still young, that's your faultThere's so much you have to go through”“But take your time, think a lotWhy think of everything you've got
For you will still be here tomorrow, but your dreams may not”“All the times that I've cried, keeping all the things I knewInsideIt's hard, but it's harder to ignore it”There’s just a few lyrics from the song that makes me think a lot about life, death and why humans deal with/process problems the way we do. I strongly encourage you to give this one a listen, it’s a great track.

How do You Sleep by John Lennon A completely hateful, spiteful, poisonous, venomous tirade against his best friend, former bandmate, and second half of the greatest songwriting team known Lennon and McCartney, Paul McCartney. Why is it depressing you might ask? Because it shows just how low John could sink to hurt one of the only two people to love him unconditionally. In fact all of these years later Paul still makes excuses for any of John's bad or anti social behavior. John knew where people's jugular veins were and didn't hesitate to go for them. Most especially those who loved him and he loved most.  Paul McCartney, Pryamus and John Lennon, Thisbe in a scene from A Midsummer Night's Dream.
